timeline.message: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:apereo/cas into inwebo

timeline.bodyText: This doesn't seem right. You are not actually doing authentication, when the method asks for doAuthentication. The credential needs to be verified somehow. If you're doing that elsewhere, you'd need to move that logic into the handler here.
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText:
I had that in mind. This is done on purpose. Let me explain.
In fact, for the push notification, we need to call Inwebo to check if the user has accepted the notification on his mobile/desktop app. The response can be "yes" or "timeout" if the user has waited too long or "refused" if the user has refused. But this can also be "wait" if the user has not accepted yet and there remains time. And in that case, we must come back on the "waiting screen".
This is why I control this behavior in a webflow action: https://github.com/apereo/cas/pull/5001/files#diff-f8b3de0873b2467c5a3d782d751949279eec743827a82a353b33ee9795cdbaacR59
For the browser authentication, I reused the same logic to only have one InweboCredential and InweboAuthenticationHandler for both authentication methods (mobile/desktop + browser).
Does it make sense?
replies.author: leleuj

replies.bodyText:
I don't entirely follow. I guess the real question is, what does it really mean to authenticate with Inwebo? At some point somewhere, you would be receiving a response back from that service that needs validation right? That response needs to be validated by the handler which is the actual act of authentication. What you have here as an authentication handler is not actually handling any sort of authentication. It's stub code, and therefore it's inconsistent with all other handlers we have.
If the response is "wait until the user responds", you don't need to invoke the authentication handler just yet. You'd wait until the response is something that can be in fact validated, right? The only time you need to invoke the handler is when there is something that can be terminally validated, and for sure, the validation must happen in the handler, and the entire authentication engine machinery that goes along with it. Otherwise, it doesn't make much sense to have a handler in the engine that basically does nothing other than to satisfy some webflow weirdness. That's an implementation nuance that creeping into the authentication handler/manager engine and should be avoided.
I am happy to lend a hand in this area and propose alternatives, if you think that would be helpful.
replies.author: mmoayyed

timeline.message: Fix the javadoc and add the RefreshScope annotation
Merge branch 'inwebo' of github.com:leleuj/cas into inwebo

timeline.bodyText: Switch type to SpringResource instead
timeline.author: mmoayyed
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,67 @@
+package org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.mfa;
+
+import org.apereo.cas.configuration.support.RequiredProperty;
+import org.apereo.cas.configuration.support.RequiresModule;
+
+import lombok.Getter;
+import lombok.Setter;
+import lombok.experimental.Accessors;
+import org.springframework.core.io.Resource;
+
+/**
+ * The Inwebo MFA properties.
+ *
+ * @author Jerome LELEU
+ * @since 6.4.0
+ */
+@RequiresModule(name = "cas-server-support-inwebo-mfa")
+@Getter
+@Setter
+@Accessors(chain = true)
+public class InweboMultifactorProperties extends BaseMultifactorProviderProperties {
+
+    /**
+     * Provider id by default.
+     */
+    public static final String DEFAULT_IDENTIFIER = "mfa-inwebo";
+
+    private static final long serialVersionUID = -942637204816051814L;
+
+    /**
+     * The Inwebo serviceId.
+     */
+    @RequiredProperty
+    private Long serviceId;
+
+    /**
+     * The location of the client certificate (PKCS12 format).
+     */
+    @RequiredProperty
+    private transient Resource clientCertificate;

replies.bodyText: I can't find the SpringResource class, in which package/jar is it?
replies.author: leleuj

replies.bodyText: OK. I changed that to use SpringResourceProperties. I also supplemented the springws dependency and remove the new springwsclient I added.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText: Please rename the class to carry the MFA provider name, much like other MFA components to be consistent; something like InweboAuthenticationDeviceMetadata... etc
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText: I will rename it.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText: Does this really need to be a bean? If so, please prefix all bean names to use inwebo. I ask the question because, is it possible for spring-ws auto-configuration to be affected by this bean? Is it going to be pick up every bean that is of type Jaxb2Marshaller? Will this interfere with some other module that wants to have their own Jaxb2Marshaller?
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText:
This must be at least renamed as it could conflict yes.
But it's certainly better to inline it inside the consoleAdmin() method. Will do that.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText: Wouldn't you be able to just merge the 3 beans that exist here to the InweboAuthenticationConfiguration class? Why a separate config?
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText:
I'd prefer to keep the Inwebo services dedicated beans in a separate bean configuration.
Though, I propose to rename it InweboServiceConfiguration to make things clearer.
replies.author: leleuj

replies.bodyText: I renamed InweboConfiguration into InweboServiceConfiguration.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText: You should not preferably spin up an isolated trust-manager; rather you should be using one that is provided by CAS automatically so the behavior of the trust-manager can be controlled via settings. I believe this is done in the util or web module where the http-client is constructed.
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText:
Indeed, there is a DefaultCasSslContext which is used in CasCoreHttpConfiguration for the HTTP client.
Though, the trustManagers of the DefaultCasSslContext, nor the DefaultCasSslContext itself are exposed.
So the idea here is to expose them to use this DefaultCasSslContext to get the built trustManagers, right?
replies.author: leleuj

replies.bodyText: OK. This is committed. I re-use the casSslContext if it exists to get its trustManagers.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText: Please prefix all webflow actions to carry the MFA provider name, similar to simple-mfa or Duo.
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText: This makes sense. I will rename all SWF actions.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText: This is unnecessary. Use StaticEventExecutionAction#SUCCESS instead.
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText: Will do
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText: It's not clear if this method is overriding something from the parent class? If not, why not mark this as a static method?
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText: I can't mark it as static as I use the getWebServiceTemplate() parent method.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText: Mark as static, and make sure you're finding/registering jackson modules as other instances of mapper do.
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText: Yes, I will change that.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText: SSLContext should not be constructed manually, but should be obtained from the runtime; there is one already available for you.
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText:
This is my specific SSLContext with my specific client certificate for Inwebo. This is why I build it manually.
I can't re-use the default one nor change the default one.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText: Possible to use a URL builder to avoid string-concatenation and encoding params manually?
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText: OK. I will use the Spring UriComponentsBuilder.

timeline.bodyText: If this is necessary, it feels like something that can be moved to a Utils class somewhere in the util module.

replies.bodyText: Sure. I'd prefer keep the original names for the generated SOAP classes. They are already in a soap package.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText: Can be obtained from the request-context. Shouldn't have to pass it in?
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText: I don't know how to do that. Can you elaborate? Thx
replies.author: leleuj

replies.bodyText: @mmoayyed This is one of the latest point if you can provide me some guidance on this...
replies.author: leleuj

replies.bodyText:
Sorry I missed this.
To deal with the message bundles, you want to use 	RequestContext.getMessageContext which will give you a message-context that you can fetch messages or add messages via keys. This is specially the recommended choice for SWF actions; you shouldn't have to directly deal with the message source itself.
replies.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText: OK. Done. I have removed the injected MessageSource to use the requestContext.getMessageContext().
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText: You shouldn't need to implement a constants interface to use what's in it, unless it actually represents a type. Remove the clause, and use the constants directly with a qualified class name to be easy on the reader.

replies.bodyText: OK. Will do.
